Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Collaborative Research: Transition Metal Oxide Nanoarchitectures for Photoelectrochemical Hydrogen Generation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conversion of solar energy into solar fuels provides long-term storage and transport of the world?s most abundant but intermittent source of energy. In the transition from fossil fuels to hydrogen as an energy carrier, materials science will play an unprecedented role. Significant materials challenges exist in the production and storage of hydrogen related to development of renewable hydrogen energy based technologies. This joint effort between the University of Maryland and the Dayalbagh Educational Institute in Agra, India, implements a systematic study focusing on design, synthesis and evaluation of inexpensive, abundant and stable transition metal oxide semiconductor materials, hematite, titania and copper oxide, with end applications in photoelectrochemical production of hydrogen. The team brings together expertise in nanomaterials synthesis and characterization (US/India), and photoelectrochemistry (India). The objective is to improve the state-of-the-art for this class of photoactive materials through careful integration of synthesis, characterization, and simulation, and to use this basis for substantial fundamental advances in materials design.

Through scientific exchange, as well as exchanges of personnel, the team develops significant intellectual infrastructure for materials research, as well as optimizes use of instruments and facilities at each of the partner institutions in this international collaboration. Beyond the laboratory, recognizing that advances in materials science will not be translated into improved quality of life without a well-trained scientific and engineering workforce, the multidisciplinary and multinational team and the timely topic of materials for hydrogen generation will attract and retain more students in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) pipeline.

This award is co-funded by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have conducted a systematic experimental study focusing on design, synthesis and evaluation of inexpensive, abundant and stable transition metal oxide semiconductor materials, hematite, titania and copper oxide, with end applications in photoelectrochemical production of hydrogen. This team brings together expertise in nanomaterials synthesis and characterization (US/India) and photoelectrochemistry (India).  Investigators and students at two institutions participated: Dayalbagh Educational Institute in Agra, India, the University of Maryland, College Park.  Our efforts have improved the state of the science for this class of photoactive materials through careful integration of synthesis, characterization, and performance evaluation. 

The scope of the work included studies of single component thin film and nanostructured hematite, copper oxide, titania, zinc oxide, barium titanate and strontium titanate as well as composite mixtures of oxides and mixtures of carbon and oxides.  Flame synthesis, spray pyrolysis, sol-gel, electrochemical deposition, and chemical vapor deposition, were used and post synthesis materials modification including swift heavy ion irradiation was studied.

Both India and the US face challenges with respect to energy utilization. India’spresent situation is more acute, with energy generation and distribution problems hampering economic growth and slowing improvement in quality of life. However, both countries share the same general concern – reliance on imported and ever costlier sources of energy and both countries are looking towards conversion to a hydrogen-based economy. In the rush to new solutions, however, it is important to consider the long-term impact of any technology. We selected these transition metal oxide systems of interest for hydrogen generation because of their potential for low life cycle cost as compared to higher efficiency compound semiconductor heterostructures, once raw material costs, manufacturing, lifetime and disposal considerations are taken into account. We have also put our team together with an emphasis on long-term impact. Through scientific exchange, as well as exchanges of personnel, we have developed significant intellectual infrastructure for materials research, as well as optimize use of instruments and facilities at each of the partner institutions in this international collaboration. Beyond the laboratory, recognizing that advances in materials science will not be translated into improved quality of life without a well-trained scientific and engineering workforce, we have exploited the excitement of working in our multidisciplinary and multinational team and the timely topic of materials for hydrogen generation in our efforts to attract and retain more students in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) pipeline.
